s.text: These are men and women who have lost homes, hopes, wives, husbands, children, illusions.
He still inhabited his own liminal realm--a Yiddish writer living in America, an American writer creating fiction in Yiddish.
This is a man who, seeing a full moon rise beautifully in the sky, feels moved to announce, "Oh, if only I could piss all over it!"
This was true of Singer himself, who has a good deal in common with his hero, Grein.
Grein is the central consciousness of the book, a man who, once a brilliant Talmud scholar in Poland and then a student of secular philosophy, is now a half-hearted mutual-fund manager in America.
Asked what became of her first husband, a profligate actor, Anna remarks matter-of-factly: "It was thought he was murdered by the Nazis but what's the saying?
The Holocaust merely added a horrible twist to their rebellion.
